name: Ginkgo Biloba
summary: Ginkgo biloba is a herbal supplement derived from the leaves of the ginkgo tree, traditionally used to support cognitive function, circulation, and mood, though clinical evidence is mixed.
description: Ginkgo biloba extract (GBE) is one of the most widely used herbal medicines worldwide, derived from the leaves of the Ginkgo biloba tree. It contains flavonoids, terpenoids, and other phytochemicals with antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and vasoregulatory properties. Ginkgo is often promoted for enhancing memory, improving circulation, reducing anxiety, and treating dementia-related symptoms. While some studies suggest modest benefits in cognitive function and anxiety, large-scale clinical trials have shown inconsistent results, and its use remains controversial in evidence-based medicine. It is, however, generally regarded as safe and is among the most popular supplements for brain health.

metadata.natural_source: Leaves of the Ginkgo biloba tree
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for medical indications)

contraindications: Concurrent anticoagulant or antiplatelet use (e.g., warfarin, aspirin)

items: Used for symptoms of dementia and cognitive decline (variable evidence)
Promotes circulatory health and vascular function

sections.text: Ginkgo biloba extract contains flavonoids and terpenoids with antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activity. It is thought to enhance cerebral blood flow, reduce platelet aggregation, and protect against oxidative neuronal damage. These mechanisms may underlie its proposed cognitive, anxiolytic, and circulatory benefits.

adult.typical: 120–240 mg standardized extract daily, divided into 2–3 doses
adult.note: Clinical studies often use standardized EGb 761 extract.

sections.text: Cognitive and circulatory benefits may require consistent use for 4–6 weeks; acute anxiolytic effects, if present, may occur within hours to days.

serious: Increased bleeding risk (rare but clinically important)

other: May increase bleeding risk, especially when combined with anticoagulants or before surgery.
Efficacy in dementia is modest and inconsistent across studies.
Use caution in individuals with seizure disorders, as rare reports of seizure exist.

sections.pregnancy: Not recommended; insufficient safety data and potential bleeding risk
sections.lactation: Avoid due to lack of safety data
sections.geriatrics: Widely used; monitor for bleeding and medication interactions

sections.text: Not required; can discontinue without withdrawal.

items: Most clinical research uses standardized extracts such as EGb 761.
Efficacy in dementia and cognitive decline is debated; some meta-analyses show small benefits, while others show no significant effect.
Patients on anticoagulants should avoid ginkgo unless supervised by a healthcare provider.
